Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: West Antarctic Ice Sheet stability, Alpine Glaciation, and Climate Variability: a Terrestrial Perspective from Cosmogenic-nuclide Dating in McMurdo Sound
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The PIs propose to complement the ANDRILL marine record with a terrestrial project that will provide chronological control for past fluctuations of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and alpine glaciers in McMurdo Sound. The project will develop high-resolution maps of drifts deposited from grounded marine-based ice and alpine glaciers on islands and peninsulas in McMurdo Sound. In addition, the PIs will acquire multi-clast/multi-nuclide cosmogenic analyses of these mapped drift sheets and alpine moraines and use regional climate modeling to shed light on the range of possible environmental conditions in the McMurdo region during periods of grounded ice expansion and recession. The PIs will make use of geological records for ice sheet and alpine glacier fluctuations preserved on the flanks of Mount Discovery, Black Island, and Brown Peninsula. Drifts deposited from grounded, marine-based ice will yield spatial constraints for former advances and retreats of the WAIS. Moraines from alpine glaciers, hypothesized to be of interglacial origin, could yield a first-order record of hydrologic change in the region. Synthesizing the field data, the team proposes to improve the resolution of existing regional-scale climate models for the Ross Embayment. The overall approach and anticipated results will provide the first steps towards linking the marine and terrestrial records in this critical sector of Antarctica.

Broader impacts:
Results from the proposed work will be integrated with outreach programs at Boston University, Columbia University, and Worcester State University. The team will actively collaborate with the American Museum of Natural History to feature this project prominently in museum outreach. The team will also include a PolarTREC teacher as a member of the research team. The geomorphological results will be presented in 3D at Boston University?s Antarctic Digital Image Analyses Lab. The research will form the basis of a PhD dissertation at Boston University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Evaluating future Sea level change is among the most important challenges facing geosciences. One major concern is the stability of the remaining polar ice-sheets in the near-future, and the West Antarctic Ice Sheet could be particularly vulnerable as it is marine-based and warming ocean waters could trigger a rapid melt.

Within this research, our team has developped new geochronologic techniques with the goal to provide new and direct ways to evaluate the stability of different sectors of the Antarctic Ice Sheets under past climate conditions, which is arguably the most robust way to test the sensitivity of these ice-sheets.

To that end, our major goal of in this project was to produce a robust chronology of mountain glacier fluctuations in the McMurdo Dry Valleys (see Fig. 1 for an example of the landscape and moraines forming the base of this project, and Fig. 2 for an example of a geomorphic map produced by this project) over the last million years and beyond using a variety of geochronological tools, including novel cosmogenic nuclide techniques. Cosmogenic nuclide techniques have transformed our understanding of Antarctic geomorphology and ice- and glacier-response, but the problem of 'pre-exposed' samples -surface samples that carry the inventory from previous periods of surface exposure and thus yield older ages than those of the last glacier advance- remain a limitation that is particularly problematic in Antarctica. This project shows that one promising path forwards to improve this, is to combine multiple cosmogenic and other geochronological tools.

This challenge is tackled in two ways in this collaborative project: (i) establishing radiocarbon chronologies from algae deposited in pro-glacial lakes connected to late Pleistocene moraines and drift-limits in the Dry Valleys (lead by Dave Marchant, Boston University), and (ii) establishing multi-nuclide surface exposure chronologies of ice-margin sediments (lead by Lamont PIs Schaefer and Winckler).

The major outcomes of this project are as follows:

- Mountain glaciers in the McMurdo region of Antarctica likely retreated through the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) period. This would point to Antarctic mountain glaciers being most sensitives to changes in snow accumulation, which decreased during the LGM. This strengthens the view, that Antarctic mountain glaciers could be valuble measures of past precipitation changes of Antarctic climate.

- The late deglaction of grounded ice in the McMurdo region after the LGM in Antarctica that began later than 13 ka ago suggests that the contribution to the most dramatic meltwater pulse in recent geologic history, refered to as Melt Water Pulse-1A (MWP-1A), from this sector of Antarctica was very limited. Similar studies should continue to narrow down the regional MWP-1A contributions from Antarctica, one of the key questions of paleo-climate, but wherever the abrupt ice-sheet melting event triggering MWP-1A came from, it seems unlikely that it happened in the McMurdo region.

- We added a new important and widely applicable geochronologic tool that is now readily avalibable to the wider community: Burial age dating and ice-sheet stability studies using sub-ice bedrock and 3He-36Cl analyses is now possible.
